facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 42 to 44 of 1959 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 42 to 44 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeals from Rajasthan High Court judgment and order dated August 9, 1957 in Civil Writ Petitions Nos. 400 to 402 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the final judament and order dated August 9, 1957, of the Rajasthan High Court  Jaipur Bench  at Jaipur in Civil Writ Petitions Nos. 400 to 402 of 1954.

facts.text: Appellant in CA 42: Automobile Transport (Raj.) Ltd., Ajmer.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants in the there appeals are  1  the Automobile Transport  Raj.  Ltd., Ajmer in Civil Appeal No. 42 of 1959.

facts.text: Appellant in CA 43: Rajasthan Roadways Ltd., Ajmer.

anchor.surface_text: 2  the Rajasthan Roadways Ltd., Ajmer in Civil Appeal No. 43 of 1959, and

facts.text: Appellant in CA 44: Framji C. Framji and others.

anchor.surface_text: 3  Framji C. Framji and others in Civil Appeal No. 44 of 1959.

facts.text: First two appellants are private limited companies registered under Indian Companies Act, 1913 with registered offices at Ajmer.

anchor.surface_text: The first two Appellants are private, limited liability companypanies registered under the Indian Companies Act, 1913 and having their registered offices at Ajmer.

facts.text: Third appellant is partnership firm named Framji Motor Transport registered under Indian Partnership Act.

anchor.surface_text: The third appellant is a partnership firm named Framji Motor Transport registered under the India Partnership Act.

facts.text: Appellants carried on business of plying stage carriages.

anchor.surface_text: These three appellants carried on the business of plying stage carriages.

facts.text: First appellant had nine transport vehicles plying between Nasirabad and Deoli in Ajmer and Ajmer to Kishangarh in Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: The first appellant bad nine transport vehicles plying between two stations in the State of Ajmer and between Ajmer and Kishangarh, a town in Rajasthan at the relevant period. The two stations in Ajmer were Nasirabad and Deoli.

facts.text: Road from Nasirabad to Deoli mainly in Ajmer but passed through narrow strips of Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: The road from Nasirabad to Deoli was mainly in the former State of Ajmer but for some distance it passed through certain narrow strips of territory of the State of Rajasthan.

facts.text: Road from Ajmer to Kishangarh partly in Ajmer and partly in Rajasthan, approx two-thirds in Ajmer one-third in Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, the road from Ajmer to Kishangarh was partly in the former State of Ajmer and partly in the State of Rajasthan, approximately two-thirds of the road lying in Ajmer and one-third in Rajasthan.

facts.text: Second and third appellants had vehicles plying on Nasirabad-Deoli route or Kishangarh to Sarwar in Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: The second and the third appellant also had some transport vehicles which plied on the Nasirabad-Deoli route or from Kishangarh to Sarwar, a town situated on the Nasirabad-Deoli road in the State of Rajasthan.

facts.text: Rajasthan Motor Vehicles Taxation Act, 1951 (Rajasthan Act XI of 1951) passed.

anchor.surface_text: On the passing of the Rajasthan Motor Vehicles Taxation Act, 1951  Rajasthan Act XI of 1951   hereinafter referred to as the Act ,

facts.text: Tax demanded by second respondent for period April 1, 1951 to March 31, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: the second respondent demanded of the appellants payment of the tax due on their motor Vehicles for the period beginning on April 1, 195 1, and ending on March 3 1, 1954.

facts.text: Tax amounts: first appellant Rs. 22,260; second Rs. 6,540; third Rs. 10,260 under r.23.

anchor.surface_text: The first appellant was called upon to pay Rs. 22,260, the second appellant Rs. 6,540 and the third appellant Rs. 10,260 under r. 23 of the Rajasthan Motor Vehicles Taxation Rules.

facts.text: Certificates issued under s.13 of Act to third respondent (Collector) for recovery as arrears of land revenue.

anchor.surface_text: When the appellants failed to pay the tax demanded from them, the second respondent issued certificates under s. 13 of the Act to the, third respondent for the recovery of the tax due as arrears of land revenue.

facts.text: Second and third appellants filed appeals to Transport Commissioner under s.14, dismissed October 21, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of the demand numberices the second and the third appellants filed appeals before the Transport Commissioner, Jaipur, under s. 14 of the Act. These appeals were however, dismissed by an order of the Transport Commissioner dated October 21, 1953.

facts.text: First appellant did not file appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The first appellant did number file any appeal.

facts.text: Appellants filed writ petitions in Rajasthan High Court claiming Act unconstitutional violating Art.301.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the three appellants filed three separate writ petitions in the Rajasthan High Court in which their main companytention was that the relevant provisions of the Act imposing a tax on their motor vehicles were unconstitutional and void as they companytravened the freedom of trade, companymerce and intercourse through out the territory of India declared by Art.301 of the Constitution

facts.text: Writ petitions dismissed by Division Bench on August 9, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: the writ petitions were dismissed by the Division Bench by its judgment and order dated August 9, 1957.

facts.text: Certificate under Art.132 granted by High Court on October 16, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The three appellants then moved the High Court for a certificate under Art. 132 of the Constitution which certificate the High Court granted by its order dated October 16, 1957.

facts.text: Act made by Rajpramukh on April 1, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was made by the Rajpramukh of the State of Rajasthan on April 1, 1951.

facts.text: Tax under s.4 on motor vehicles used or kept for use in Rajasthan.

issues.text: Whether ss. 4 and 11 of the Rajasthan Motor Vehicles Taxation Act, 1951 infringe the right of freedom of trade, commerce or intercourse granted under Art. 301 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, they referred the question whether ss. 4 and 11 of the Act infringed the right of freedom of trade, commerce or intercourse granted under Art. 301 of the Constitution. The Full Bench dealt with the question from two different stand points.

issues.text: Whether the relevant provisions of the Act imposing a tax on motor vehicles are unconstitutional and void as they contravene the freedom of trade, commerce and intercourse declared by Art. 301 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: their main contention was that the relevant provisions of the Act imposing a tax on their motor vehicles were unconstitutional and void as they contravened the freedom of trade, commerce and intercourse through out the territory of India declared by Art.301 of the Constitution

issues.text: Whether the provisions of the Act under which the appellants were sought to be taxed contravene Art. 301 and are not saved by Art. 304(b)

anchor.surface_text: The main argument on behalf of the appellants before us has been that the provisions of the Act under which the appellants were sought to be taxed in respect of their motor vehicles plying on the Nasirabad-Deoli or Kishangarh road contravened Art. 301 of the Constitution and were not saved by Art. 304 (b) of the Constitution.

issues.text: Is the scheme of the Act in conflict with the freedom of trade, commerce and intercourse assured by Art. 301 and other connected articles in Part XIII

anchor.surface_text: Is this scheme in conflict with the freedom of trade, commerce and intercourse within the territory of India assured by Art. 301 and other connected articles in Part XIII of the Constitution ? That is the problem before us.

arguments.claim: Atiabari majority view correct subject to clarification: regulatory/compensatory measures exempt from Art. 301

anchor.surface_text: The interpretation which was accepted by the majority in the Atiabari Tea Co. case is correct, but subject to this clarification. Regulatory measures or measures imposing compensatory taxes for the use of trading facilities do not come within the purview

holdings.text: The interpretation accepted by the majority in Atiabari Tea Co. case is correct, subject to clarification that regulatory measures or compensatory taxes for use of trading facilities do not come within purview of restrictions under Art. 301.

anchor.surface_text: The interpretation which was accepted by the majority in the Atiabari Tea Co. case  1  is correct, but subject to this clarification. Regulatory measures or measures imposing compensatory taxes for the use of trading facilities do not come within the purview of the restrictions contemplated by Art. 301 and such measures need not comply with the requirements of the proviso to Art. 304 b  of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects widest and narrow views; adopts Atiabari majority with clarification to exclude regulatory/compensatory measures that facilitate trade, avoiding paralysis of state powers.

holdings.text: Taxes imposed by Rajasthan Motor Vehicles Taxation Act are compensatory taxes for use of roads and do not hinder but facilitate trade, commerce and intercourse under Art. 301.

anchor.surface_text: The taxes are compensatory taxes which instead of hindering trade, commerce and intercourse facilitate them by providing roads and maintaining the roads in a good state of repairs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tax on vehicles using roads is for facilities provided; quantum reasonable relative to road expenditure; not direct impediment but payment for benefit.

holdings.text: Provisions of ss. 4 and 11 of the Act do not infringe freedom of trade, commerce or intercourse under Art. 301.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, they referred the question whether ss. 4 and 11 of the Act infringed the right of freedom of trade, commerce or intercourse granted under Art. 301 of the Constitution. The Full Bench dealt with the question from two different stand points.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies clarified Atiabari test; tax compensatory, not direct/immediate restriction.

holdings.text: Widest interpretation of Art. 301 (Shah J. in Atiabari) is incorrect as it ignores regulatory measures necessary for orderly society.

anchor.surface_text: The most serious objection to the widest view canvassed before us is that it ignores altogether that in the conception of freedom of trade, commerce and intercourse in a community regulated by law freedom must be understood

holdings.reasoning_summary: Would require President's sanction for all regulations, paralyzing state powers; freedom understood in context of regulated society.

holdings.text: Narrow interpretation excluding taxation from Part XIII (except Art. 304(a)) is incorrect; Art. 245 subjects all laws including taxes to constitutional provisions.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of Art. 265 was considered in the majority decision and it was pointed out that the power of taxation under our Constitution was subject to the condition that no tax shall be levied or collected except by authority of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 245 and 265 apply; taxation not exempt from Part XIII; follows Atiabari majority.

holdings.text: Regulatory measures and compensatory taxes that do not impede but facilitate trade are not hit by Art. 301.

anchor.surface_text: Such regulatory measures as do not impede the freedom of trade, commerce and intercourse and compensatory taxes for the use of trading facilities are not hit by the freedom declared by Art. 301.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examples like traffic rules, road tolls facilitate flow; distinction from prohibitive burdens.

holdings.text: Only taxes that directly and immediately restrict trade fall within Art. 301; others with indirect effect do not.

anchor.surface_text: Taxes may and do amount to restrictions but it is only such taxes as directly and immediately restrict trade that would fall within the purview of Art. 301.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Atiabari majority; vehicle tax not direct on movement but compensatory.

holdings.text: Relevant provisions of the Act are constitutional and do not contravene Art. 301; appeals dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The interpretation which was accepted by the majority in the Atiabari Tea Co. case  1  is correct, but subject to this clarification. Regulatory measures or measures imposing compensatory taxes for the use of trading facilities do not come within the purview of the restrictions contemplated by Art. 301 and such measures need not comply with the requirements of the proviso to Art. 304 b  of the Constitution.

If the Act and the Schedules appended thereto are examined in this manner, it will be noticed that the tax imposed is really a tax for the use of the roads in Rajasthan and it cannot be said that it hinders the free movement of trade, commerce and intercourse.
